awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Broadband Service Reliability: Characterization and Improvement
awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies the reliability of broadband services, explores the relation between reliability and users' quality of experience and investigates edge-based solutions to improve reliability. It develops techniques and investigates metrics to study and characterize reliability problems, and algorithms to diagnose and localize their source, building on existing infrastructure and data collected as part of the Federal Communications Commission's Measuring Broadband America effort.  This investigation explores the impact of reliability problems on users' Quality of Experience (QoE), exploring the value of possible proxy metrics for QoE (e.g., session time, traffic demand) and the application of natural experiments and related designs to understand their relationship at scale while controlling for most confounding factors.  An understanding of reliability problems, their impact and most common causes should help in the development of  readily deployable solutions that might improve service reliability at the network edge.

As residential broadband network availability and performance improves, consumers continue to migrate key services such as telephony, television and home monitoring to over-the-top alternatives. This migration comes with rising users' expectations regarding broadband reliability, which is a key factor of consumer experience. Despite the rich history of reliability engineering, researcher have very limited understanding of reliability in the context of broadband, from the most appropriate metrics for characterizing it, to approaches for gathering measurements or assessing their impact on users' quality of experience.  When reliability problems appear, troubleshooting them is nearly impossible -- there is no principled approach to determining the source of the problem. The outcome is increased frustration for users, growing management costs for Internet service providers, and, ultimately, underperforming applications. 

The project enhances undergraduate and graduate teaching, involves undergraduates in research projects, reaches out to industry, provides tools and first-of-its-kind datasets to researchers, and offers a data gathering platform and data for the benefit of Federal and State telecom regulators. The algorithms, tools, techniques and experimental approaches we will develop will help users, operators and policymakers providing a firmer statistical footing for future investment.

por.por_cntn:
Broadband availability and performance continue to improve rapidly, propelled by both government and private investment, and motivated by the recognized social and economic benefits of connectivity. In much of the developed world, broadband providers are offering sufficiently high capacities to encourage consumers to move traditional home services such as television, phone, and home monitoring to ?over-the-top? alternatives. The increasing speed and availability of broadband services, as well as the associated movement to OTT services, are raising users? expectations regarding broadband reliability. Today we have a very limited understanding of reliability in the context of broadband, from the most appropriate metrics for characterizing it, to approaches for gathering measurements or assessing its impact on users? quality of experience.

This project carried out the first study on the reliability of broadband services, its impact on quality of experience, common problems, and potential solutions. We developed techniques and explored metrics to characterize reliability, investigated common reliability problems, and explored algorithms to diagnose their causes. We studied the impact of reliability problems on users' QoE and explored the relationship between quality of service metrics, leveraging our datasets and industry collaboration. We explored the applicability of alternative experimental design approaches, including natural experiments, regression-discontinuity design, and instrumental-variable design. We conducted the first characterization of deployed In-Flight Communication systems and explored an approach to improve users' web experience by dynamically reducing the complexity of websites rendered based on network conditions. We carried out the first study of AMP to understand its design and advantages under a variety of settings and extract any ``exportable'' lessons. We studied the criticality of the submarine cable network (SCN) from the perspective of Internet end users and demonstrated, for the first time, that a large fraction of the resources accessed by end-users around the world relies on the submarine cable network, and that is the case even for users located in landlocked countries. The project resulted in several publications in top-rated peer review conferences in the field, and software releases of AlwaysOn, a system that uses MultiPath TCP to improve broadband reliability, and ScaleUp, a Chrome extension that measures and dynamically adjusts every page you load to improve your quality of experience while browsing. It also resulted in the release of addendums to the FCC MBA report focused on reliability, together with an interactive chart for ISP reliability. 

The project was also the training ground for several undergraduate students, graduate students, and a postdoctoral fellow, who have developed expertise in network measurement, experimentation, network topology and analysis, and routing protocols. The research included the work of a few Ph.D. students, including one whose thesis was primarily based on the research founded by this grant.
